Violett is a challenge. Not necessarily because the puzzles are extremely hard or because the game play is terrible. Simply because it's a point and click puzzle game and they tend to come with their own brand of problems.

That said, I found Violett enjoyable. (For the record, if you don't like point and clicks, don't play this. It will drive you up the wall. I've seen a few reviews by people who said they don't usually play point and clicks, so why on earth did they play this?)

If you love point and clicks go buy this game now, if you're on the fence read on.

Violett is the usual Point and Click affair, there’s a puzzle and you have to solve it. You might have some inventory items and you may need to backtrack every so often in order to get all the pieces. All that stuff is in Violett, if you're a fan of something like the Monkey Island series you'll feel right at home here. Violett differentiates itself through its mysterious nature

Violett is a world where nothing seems to make sense and there’s a lack of cohesion between levels, and that’s a good thing. It represents how crazy this world Violett is in and keeps things fresh and non-repetitive.

There’s no comprehensible language, as such you learn everything about the world visually and through interactions with other characters. They do have speech bubbles but they’re filled with various pictures/drawings and from that you have to solve the puzzles.

While this helps the narrative of Violett and brings a sense of mystery and wonder, it’s also where a large portion of the frustrations come from. Sometimes objectives are unclear and you’ll spend more time trying to work out what the objective is rather than trying to solve the puzzle. Violett does its best to alleviate this issue but it doesn’t always succeed.

Violett features a really nice soundtrack, though they feel more like compositions than BGM. It comes free with the game so you may as well give it a listen! The songs for the most part are well choreographed with the background images.

The scenery is of a high standard and there’s enough going on that you can spend a large amount of time just taking it all in. In saying that Violett does seem to stand out very harshly in some of the environments and while it can be said this is to show how she’s out of place, it sometimes ruins these amazing backdrops. This isn’t always the case though and is only something you notice in the more simplistic levels.

Thanks for reading my review! Check out the video and follow the channel, I do Indie Game reviews nearly every day!

For a point-and-click adventure, you're either going to enjoy this game or you're going to hate it. The initial premise evokes strong deja-vu of Coraline almost to the point of feeling like a blatent ripoff. You play Violett, a goth girl who moves into an old house and finds herself lost in a strange world - complete with a spider antagonist. This is where the simularities end however... as well as the depth of story. Simply put, if you're someone who prefers a heaping dose of narrative and gets annoyed when things are left vague, this game isn't for you. If you don't mind a game that gives you the breadcrumbs and encourages your own interpretations, you'll find an adventure reminiscent of Alice in Wonderland or The Neverending Story.

Each scenery you'll encounter is incredibly imaginitive, from opera singing frogs who can control the weather with their voice, to haunted teapots that torment their owners. The puzzles can be frustrating, but for the most part are never truly illogical. Well, I just got done with Violett and I must say there's a lot that's both good and bad.

The Good:

Overall, I found the experience charming. The art is excellent, most (but not all) of the puzzles are challenging but not impossible, and I liked the hidden item collection. The Machinarium-style pictograms were a good choice, making localization a breeze.  Music was great too, and I appreciate the OST coming with the Steam release sale.

The Not So Good:

The hint system is TERRIBLE!  Totally tells you nothing you need to know. Plus, some of the puzzles aren't tremendously intuitive, and when you suddenly need to start backtracking after a series of self-contained rooms it's unexpected.  The hidden item aspect, which I do like, actually makes no sense in terms of mana since you never use it. I haven't tried, but I expect you can finish the game quite handily without picking up a single bit of mana throughout which makes it pointless except to gain an achievement.  Finally, there's the rather inexplicable ending scene which I suspect was intended to be interactive but somehow plays automatically.  Makes no sense in context, since you haven't seen or heard about this character from the beginning, so it's quite confounding.

I should make special mention of the story, or rather the lack thereof. At the beginning, we are given a pretty bare-bones setup. Unhappy girl, taken to big house, finds amulet and gets sucked into another world.  And...that's pretty much all you get.  Other than a glimpse at the beginning of the game and a diary entry that you can easily miss out on, the player has NO CLUE who the villain at the end is. Even then, there's no indication if they're the one who brought you into this world. You also aren't given any idea what this place is, or how it's related to you. There's one reference that the diary belonged to your uncle, but that's the sole mention of him, so again we're lost.

Finally, there are the bugs. I only had to restart the game from the beginning once (from the library) but others have had to do it multiple times. I also ran into a couple of graphical glitches towards the end. Better quality control should have been done before this was released onto Steam, for sure.

Overall:

Despite all that, I'd still recommend the game although you might need to look in the community for hints. It is undeniably charming, and that's a large part of it for me. I just wish there were a more engaging story to go with it.

reviewText:
Violett is a delightful point and click game, though partially also a hidden object game, containing engaging puzzles, colorful and creative landscapes, and a memorable soundtrack. It's a bit of a blend between Coraline and Alice in Wonderland; you fall into this world of intelligent, sophisticated insects and tiny mammals, and are working towards freeing them from tyranny, and yourself from being tinier then a mouse.

What I liked best about this game was easily the setting and the audio. The maps were colorful, a creative mix of exotic flavors and household objects, and the mini game of finding all of the hidden objects (there's an achievement involved with that) helps you explore and appreciate it a little more thoroughly. The music...it's charming, and cute, and gets stuck in your head easily. I'm a fool for a neat artstyle, and both the powers you use in the game, and the style of the game, reminded me a bit of Psychonauts. While the plot isn't directly spelled out for you, journal pages and direct observation provide the bulk of the simple, age-old story.

Mechanically, the game was decently smooth. It was always clear where you could go, the pathing was very fluid, and the animations never glitched or did anything unpredictable. There was no mad clicking, and whenever it required anything different then clicking, a helpful icon would appear at the bottom of the screen telling the player to drag the mouse in a certain direction.

There are a couple of known glitches at the time this review was made, though they didn't retract from the game. One is an unclickable orb, which does not prevent the achievement from granting, and the other is around an area called the Labyrinth, where the game crashes while saving. It saves successfully, and autosaves frequently, so you won't lose any progress, but might need to restart in that area a couple of times. While yes, it's not perfect, it hardly bothered me and was the last time I saw a glitch in the game, in that early area.

The major topic of the puzzles...The one every fears and has a great deal of conflict on, whether puzzles are understandable and readable, or if they are counter-intuitive and too hard. To my perspective, Violett is not difficult to understand. There's visual cues in every level, detailing what you should be focusing on. In every level, there's either interaction with NPCs who directly tell you what they require from you, or a visible problem that you must correct to proceed. A couple of the early levels are actually the toughest, involving long puzzles with back and forth steps required, and items from different areas necessary to complete puzzles from previous areas. The game actually gets progressively easier and more intuitive, which I wasn't expecting, the puzzles later on being far more isolated within their given screens or pathway forks.

Over all calls? This game is worth playing for it's creative atmosphere and decent puzzles. It has a couple of issues, but the puzzles follow the logic of the story, and at no point did I ever hit a wall. New content and glitch fixes have been added recently, so it clearly gets attention from it's developers.


((Ways to improve the game? More visual cues, looking at the reviews. Maybe unique sounds for when the screens are complete, or all the orbs are gone from a screen, or a puzzle mechanic is finished. The newly added content was maybe even a little better then the original content, and didn't feel forced or shoehorned in.))

reviewText:
Point and click games generally have three factors that determine its quality: story, art style, and puzzles.

This game has a rather simplistic straightforward story, so don't expect any plot twists, internal conflicts, or multiple endings. In addition, even though the story is largely derivative of Lewis Caroll's Alice in Wonderland, the diary pages do provide some interesting and amusing backstory to the characters that you meet along the way.

In terms of art style, Violett has some very pleasing hand painted 2D background art and the 3D models are not too shabby either. Also, don't fret about turning this game's graphical quality up to the highest. It barely causes the fan of my low end graphics card to spin faster.

Finally, the puzzles and challenges of this game aren't too difficult provided that one has a keen eye in spotting patterns and hidden clues. Also, the game has a hint system for those that are stuck on a particular puzzle. Of course, if you choose to use it you won't qualify for certain achievements.

Overall, this is a point and click game is with an emphasis on puzzles and challenges. If one is looking for something akin to the Deponia series or The Longest Journey, then one isn't going to find it here in this game.

reviewText:
Violett bridges the gap between classic point&click and the causal gaming 'busy picture' genre, and tries to make more use of touch functionality doing so.


The art is fantastic, the story bits are funny and contain great humor. The character design is one really neat piece (I love that snails :D), and the fantasy-setting Violett finds herself in is a refreshing approach to the genre. There are one or two translation errors in the found diary pages, but since they are 'only' flavortext, this does not matter much.

The puzzles are nicely tailored and make sense most of the time, but this is where my ranting starts.

The logic of the riddles is not very consistant leaving the player to simply grab unreachable objects by magic in one case, and completely ignoring this ability in another, similar case. Also there are some timing-based riddles, where you need to hit the right spot at the right time. The Bossfight - just so much: collect as much of those 'orbs' as possible, you will need them.

Especially the 'dynamic' puzzles and the 'swipe' mechanic might feel pretty alien to someone who is used to point and clicks, but I recon it a worthy experiment.

All in all the game is not as frustrating as it seems to be, it's not too short… just a nice, and really sweet looking short story.



It's absolutely charming, neatly drawn, and certainly worth your money if you like dream-like fantasy, insect kingdoms, 'shrunken characters', busy-picture games, magic, fairies, or just quirky non-mainstream art.

I bought this game because it looked like a gorgeous point and click adventure game that I could play when I wanted something that was a little more relaxed than some of my other games. What I got was 3 hours of frustration that got me no where.

There is no direction. Occasionally little thought bubbles pop up to help you, but if you miss them they won't pop back up. If you get stuck too long there are supposed to be hints...but usually they were either completely unhelpful, or it was an action that you couldn't do just yet, or I'd miss it all together because if you're not paying attention you won't notice the faint sparkle that indicates your target. There are also sheets of with notes about some of the characters you seem to run into...but they fail to include any information on how to get past them.

Then, when you finally think you've figured it out, the actions don't always work, or they require you just clicking repeatedly until they do what they should. I had only made it as far as the second room when attempting to control a buzzing fly drove me nearly insane with clicking.

You collect little stones but have no idea why. There's a little animation that appears in the corner sometimes indicating I should move my mouse side to side? I think? But I have no idea why. I'm not sure if it's a hint or what. Having no idea why seemed to be the theme generally.

On top of all this, the game was glitchy and had to be restarted a couple of times because all my actions froze, which I know was an issue with my friend playing as well.

I love a good challenge, but randomly clicking all over a screen hoping something will happen is just frustrating and left me wanting my money back.

reviewText:
Violett is a point and click adventure game. It's story is told through your actions as violett, and the game's imagery(mostly without words, the diary pages being the exception). This is a really cool concept, letting the player discover the story through the gameplay and not the other way around. However even with the games very pleasant artwork, and smooth animations The game struggles.

The puzzles are very unintuitive, and the game carries very little direction for the player to follow. Most of the time spent in the game is wandering aimlessly around trying to figure out what to do next. A puzzle's hardness should not be defined by it's lack of clarity, in an attempt to elongate game time. Most point and click games have some amount of vagueness to them, but this one kind of takes it to a new level. There is a pretty generous hint system in the game, but you shouldn't NEED that hint system to progress.

Other than walking around and solving some puzzles you have the ability to collect colored orbs, which is less optional then the game lets on. These little orbs are power for your abilities that you will need to fight the final boss. So if you spent the game ignoring them and ou get to the end, you'll find yourself having to do a lot of backtracking to tediously comb over completed areas. It can be a bit fun looking for the little trap doors, or moving objects to find them, but several of them are behind immovable scenery and are effectively invisible. Meaning unless you get lucky clicking around, or pick up a guide you won't find them. There is also no real way to know if you've found all the orbs in one area, making the whole thing a bit difficult for no real reason.

My last big gripe against the game are the glitches. The controls aren't great, so sometimes you end up getting stuck in one spot and are unable to leave that spot (I got stuck in the library next to the weather book, and a few other places where my icons just dissapeared, looking for orbs).I immediately went to quit the game without realizing that even though I had saved in another slot, it would continue to auto save over my manual save, leaving me trapped on the book case unable to do anything. I had to start over. It was partially my fault for not being more careful, but if you're going to force players to re-search areas having glitches like that are pretty annoying.

On the positive side I found the art very pleasing, And the diary pages' snippets of inhabitant lore very cool. Those two elements very clearly had a lot of hard work and love put into them.

Overall, I don't recommend the game, because pretty art, and tidbits of interesting lore don't make up for the gameplay it lacked.

TLDR;
Pros: nice artwork, some cool world lore.

Cons: unintuitive puzzles and gameplay, lots of wandering around aimlessly, Hard-to-find-for-no-reason orbs, lots of backtracking to pad the game, glitches that may cause you to restart entirely.

As you can tell, I didn't get that far.

Game just didn't grab me.

I like point n click games, this is just one of them that I don't like. This game just makes me want to play Monkey Island again.

It's... not even a BAD game. It's just not one I foresee myself ever playing ever again. I looked at the game, and the graphics weren't nearly charming enough to make me keep playing. That's what happened. I had no fun, I clicked things, nothing interesting happened.

Maybe one day I'll actually play it all the way through. For now I'm rating it down, because I was expecting to be thrilled by a fascinating new universe - instead I feel disappointed. I was promised a gorgeous world.

Some people have mentioned it was made for mobile devices. If so I absolutely see what's wrong: there's nothing for me to gawk at.

Bastion was a bright and vibrant game too, with graphics I found far more charming. And that was completely 2D. That's what Violett should have been in the first place: entirely 2D with entirely hand-drawn animations and art. The guys who made this game seem to pride themselves on that, so lets see some more of it. 3D models that look this poor are just unappealing to look at.

I'm not whining about the quality of graphics. I'm not saying it needs to be in Unreal Engine 4 with godrays and cel-shading. I'm not saying everything needs to be a 300,000 polygon model with 4096x4096 textures or anything. I just wish that they'd stuck with one thing. Stretched out on my desktop, this game just doesn't look good.

Monkey Island still looks good, it's charming, funny, and has voice acting on every character, leading the world to feel far more alive than it would otherwise - for instance, in Violett.

Maybe this genre should stay dead.

reviewText:
Okay... there's one very good point I will give this game, and that that it's absolutely gorgeous and imaginative. A true piece of art. If you're looking for an abstract painting (you'll recognise its inspiration, such as MC Esher), but that you can interact with a little, than you've found something you'll like. Otherwise I have many grippes with this game. After less than an hour it was too annoying and I couldn't keep playing.

First off, the interaction system is wayyy too clunky. I much prefer the good ol' verb-based system : push, pull, take, talk, etc. Here you have to actually pull stuff by making very specific motion with your mouse. And because of this, it took me the longest time to get out of the cage at the beginning. After clicking furiously all around the screen, after having poked and pulled at the paperclip to no effect I was about to give up already. Then I just went crazy on it, moving my mouse all around, and it finally fell. My only thought was : ARE YOUR SERIOUS?

So yeah, this isn't nearly as intuitive nor as charming as Monkey Island, unfortunatly. The few characters there are only speak with speech bubbles and gibberish. This would be fine if their message was interesting, but they are only boring. Yes, the characters are pretty much untinteresting at best, shallow and blank at worst. Even the main character is weird and uncharacterised. He/she never speaks, you don't really know anything about him/her except that his/her parents moved in a new house and she is pulled into this miniature dimension. It would of added a lot to have given him/her an actual voice, so he/she could give his/her thoughts about the strange world he/she got into.

The puzzles themselves seem very contrived and strange, which follows the style of the world. I guess I'm just not smart enough, but I honestly couldn't solve most of them. The problem being, I didn't even know what the problems were most of the time. One room I solved out of pure luck, distracting an evil teapot with a fly I randomly captured in a bottle. Half the time I just looked, scratching my head, trying to understand what I was looking at. If the character could at least of given me a hint or something to identify what I needed to do it would of helped. Unfortunatly, after seeing all the strange rooms and not making any progress, I decided to stop playing. Now you might decipher the cryptic solutions to these rooms, connected by a kind of MC Escher maze, but I wasn't enjoying it so I couldn't be bothered. The last straw was a room where a firework kept firing in an endless loop of ear-destroying pain, while I got posed by a piece-swapping puzzle to this noise. NO THANKS. I'M OUT.

So yeah. Very pretty game, but mechanically too frustrating. If you're the type, like me, to enjoy artsy visuals, than I recommend this. Otherwise, if you want a well put together point n' click game, look elsewhere. Unless its on sale for very cheap. If you want a number, I'll give it a 6.5, 5 points for excellent visuals plus 1.5 for playability. It just couldn't pull me in (pun intented).

reviewText:
For my First Review of 2015, the first game I've passed in 2015: Violett

Violett is a very pretty game. The Backgrounds are lovely, colourful & have an Alice in Wonderland meets Honey I shrunk the kids sort of charm. It is a point and click adventure with a cute story waiting to get out.

Unfortunately the story never really does get out. There is little narrative in any form of presentation, verbal or non verbal and even less direction. The titular young girl has some telekinetic powers which seem to be limited to the very specific items the creators did not feel like animating while other times you can practically reach an item you need but have to float a ladder over to it to climb up and retrieve it. Where are her mind powers there?
The other abilities are only used to bypass a couple of road-block hazards which themselves are only blocking collection items. One of these skills is a floating power, kind of a limited flight, which is only used in maybe three instances and yet in the many other situations where it would be a big help in reaching some place it is somehow imposable for her to use.
If this had been part platformer these abilities would have been a lot of fun to play with but as it stands they seem to be just tacked on to again cut down on animation.

That said I, having studied animation myself, understand how much time and tedium can be involved in seeming simple motions so I do not blame the creators for that trick.

Pros : Easy to pick up and play
Pretty to look at
Often available for next to nothing.

Cons: Like a lot of point and click games, the puzzles are less about intellect and more about noticing what piece of the background is a different shade or makes the arrow become a hand.
Little story development.
A lot of very slow moving to and from-ing.

Pick it up on sale if you like point and click, don't if you don't

Violett is a point-click adventure that takes inspiration from many popular stories like Coroline,Thumbelina,ALice and many other . You will be noticing many references if you watch cartoons like I do but I am not sure if its a good thing . It almost feels like game is borrowing too much from other sources .

The level design and animations look very high quality so they probably had good budget . Definetly the biggest plus of this game is the aesthetics which are superior to most games in this genre . If you like fantasy inspired worlds with slightly sinister atsmophere then I would recommend this game .

Gameplay or controls I should say are a bit wird . Normally you have a 3D character that has to come close to interact with objects but Violett combines that with a long range Hidden object gameplay. I think negative reviews for this game are based on the fact that people can't grasp that mechanic right away.

My biggest beef with Violett is lack of voice acting or even text for that matter . Violett just mumbles which is intentional design I guess but I can't say that I like it .

Many people complain that puzzles are too diffecult which is poor argument considering that target audience for this game are people who like complicated solutions . I mean its kind of what this game is (press everything you see and make sense of it if you can ) Personally I think level design was pretty good and puzzles are enjoyable .

You can use rechargable Hint so . Don't say game is hard to figure out, the cheats are build right into panel .

Anyway this game is good visual experiance . Some flaws here and there but if you a puzzle game junkie don't pass this .

reviewText:
Well. The game's art is great and so is the music. For some reason the main character is the worst looking thing in the game.

Violett moves to a spooky house in the country with her parents. She seems unhappy about it. In her room she discovers a magical amulet in a mouse hole. This takes her to a magical world of fairies and bugs. Think Coraline with a lighter tone and more colours.

This game is incredibly frustrating in many ways. Some times it's hard to know where you can walk because of the layout of the map. Some times this is solved by the creators by putting an arrow in the landscape, so I guess they realised their error and fixed it an easy way. The clickables sometimes changes the mousecursor to an 'available action' hand, some times not.

As a completelist I haven't been this frustrated about collectibles since as long as I can remember. The orbs are sometimes easy to spot, some times can only been seen from certain angles, sometimes actually invisible. Some of the hidden places are the same way; some easy to spot some you will only see in a guide.

If you miss the orbs or diary page in the first room, there is no way to go back and you'll have to start a new game if you want the completist achievements. There is also a bug that happens sometimes where Violett will get stuck for no reason and you'll have to exit and load game to fix it. As far as I can tell from internet searches and guides I collected all the diary pages needed for the achievement, yet I did not get it.

The voiceacting. I don't mind gibberish-language games, but some of the voices in this game is just plain annoying. And ofcourse the one you'll hear the most, Violett, is the most annoying of them all. The sound Violett makes when she tells you she can't do whatever action you tried to make her do, is one of the most annoying sounds ever and you feel severely punished for not clicking everything perfectly. Add to this that it's impossible to turn off the sound effects; you can only turn it down to level 1/10. All of this makes it 100% necessary to use a guide at all times, which always makes the game less fun.

Violett collects pages from her uncle's diary throughout the game, but nothing is told by the game of who the uncle is, how and why he was in the same world Violett discovered.

I bought this on 85% off and suffered 10 hours of frustration as I didn't want it to drag down my achievement collection % and always hoping that the game would improve. Turns out I still can't complete everything. Not worth.
